channel.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
channel.description:
I've been trying to have a go at making a basic RuneScape Classic bot using reflection, but I'm having trouble using any of the methods inside of the client.
I have the client loaded by the loader.jar with the rsclassic.jar, both downloaded straight off of the RuneScape website. I'm running them off of the local drive rather than the url to the jar on the RS site.
Currently this is all I have:
[IMG]http://i51.tinypic.com/xn8br4.png[/img]
I tried earlier to try to invoke a simple method inside the client, but could never get it working.
I want to invoke the method "G(int i1)" which I believe logs the player out.
This is what I am trying:
[code] Method m = RSL.getClientClass().getDeclaredMethod("G", Integer.TYPE); m.setAccessible(true); Object param = new Integer(2); m.invoke(RSL.getClientClass(), param);[/code]
And it always gives me:
[code]object is not an instance of declaring class[/code]
I think it is because my loader doesn't create a new instance of client when it loads, but rather an new instance of loader.
I don't really know where to go from here. Maybe load the client from the website rather than locally, I don't know.

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

super_:

I think you should re-read my post, I don’t have time to re-explain everything right now but it’s clear you still have some misunderstanding.

I don’t know how to write to the action queue like STS does because it’s different than the way the current client is set up.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

Hmm…

I have my interface that I want to use to inject into the client. I’ve looked up how to inject and use interfaces and it’s all clear to me what they’ve done, but all I’ve found is how to use an interface hook to return a simple value.

What I want to to (I think…) is have my interface invoke methods like you said “SendID” or something similar.

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

Not a problem. Also thanks for replying.

So you’re saying is that I want to access the “RunCommand” method rather than what I was trying with prayer?

This is the current “RunCommand” method as is appears in the decompiled client: http://pastebin.com/E8aFvLBX

I would need to create and interface to set the dfm, dfg, etc. with, then call RunCommand?

After reading through this… could I just call client.a(some int, some byte) to do the trick?

The first parameter is equal to the option ID after being converted or something through the Ac.b(int, int) method. The byte is converted to be used as the index id if you know what I mean. Like for prayer[0], prayer[1], etc.

I’m not too concerned with creating human-like patterns for this because I’m not convinced Jagex is going to ban anyone from RSC anymore.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

There isn’t a clean way to do this with reflection. Besides that, you have no guarantee reflection will work for these members at all – it relies on assumptions that only the JLS, and not the JVM specification, makes.
With obfuscated code, you can have methods of the same name with identical argument types, while you can’t do this in source code. This is because the compiler faces ambiguity, while at runtime, all invokes point to method reference constants, which internally rely on name-and-type constants – these embody an entiresignature/descriptor, which incorporates return type.

So, while:

class a { void a(int i); boolean a(int i); }

… is illegal in Java, it’s perfectly legal to the JVM:

{ class: "a", { name: "a", descriptor: "(I)V" } } { class: "a", { name: "a", descriptor: "(I)Z" } }

This also applies to fields:

class z { long z; Object z; }

{ class: "z", { name: "z", descriptor: "J" } } { class: "z", { name: "z", descriptor: "Ljava/lang/Object;" } }

Reflection however via:
Field getDeclaredField(String name)
Method getDeclaredMethod(String name, Class<?>… parameterTypes)

… only take half of the descriptor, which is assumed to be unique by the JLS. Jagex’s obfuscator, however, could easily exploit the fact the JVM doesn’t require these restraints, and render your approach useless.

Typically, people modify the client code to add their own interfaces to the client’s code. They might inject methods like “SendID” and “SendVar” which delegate to their obfuscated counterparts, handling argument reordering and dummy parameters. This way you have a consistent layer for your main bot code to interface with the code that isn’t nearly as low-level and difficult to update. This may prove to be unnecessarily low-level in itself, and you may find yourself preferring something akin to Aryan in that it utilizes /action-forcing/.

Internally, the client keeps a queue of game /actions/ to process every game tick. This queue is represented by what in STS is the “OptionId” and “OptionX/Y”, “dfm”, “dfn”, “dga” arrays. Instead of manually constructing the packet yourself in a concurrent manner (which is unsafe, btw – you may be accessing the output buffer at the same time the client is), you instead write to the slightly higher-level action queue and let the client handle the nitty-gritty data encoding. The way Aryan did this was by hijacking the client’s action processing routine, which in STS is named “RunCommand”, to push the desired actions into the queue (which is executing in the client thread and therefore safe). You may find it easier to work with the action queue than the network logic itself.

Following the Aryan mass-ban, however, most ditched this method of botting in favor of something based on synthesizing fake UI mouse events for the client, which is an even higher-level facade. This method attempts the most at being human-like however lacks the ease of implementation that action-forcing exploited. Instead it focuses all its attention on coming up with realistic mouse paths which is a very difficult problem in its own right.

I apologize for going off-topic, but hopefully you learned something

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

Setting Ii[1] to true will turn the prayer’s text green as if it is on, but it’s really not.

My current issue is being able to call the methods I posted above. Before when I was trying them the errors weren’t being printed so I just thought nothing was happening, but really I was getting exceptions.

See, hh is of type k which is a subclass of o. The method I need to call is o.c(int i1) (and others eventually). My problem is getting the instance of o that I need to pass to invoke. hh is the instance, and I don’t know how to invoke methods though hh.

And I took the numbers exactly as they appear in the current client.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

The methods you called are constructing the proper network frame to notify the server you enabled a prayer. What you’re missing out on is actually applying these changes so you see them clientside…
Notice that you still need to set Ii[1] to true; this is the client-side flag set for determining which prayers are active.

Note that your current methods only work for the client that code is from. Newer clients are also obfuscated, and therefore have different randomized argument lists as well as dummy parameters. An example of such parameters are the 117 and -95.

Client updates also have new frame opcodes; so, while 60 may have been used for the prayer activation frame in the revision you’re dealing with, in the future it may be randomized to any other legal opcode (i think the maximum width is 16-bits).

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

No problem.

I’m thinking I have to inject my own methods into the client to be able to do what I want. I don’t know know if it’s gonna work, but it’s worth a shot.

E: Nvm, I’m just stumped.

E2: The errors weren’t being printed for some reason. I can’t call the hh.a(int…) methods that I’ve been needing because they’re not an instance of the declaring class. I need to invoke o.a(int); through the client’s hh field.

Read full topic

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

It is working how I want it to, and now I’m sort of stuck again.

This is (I’m almost certain) the method for turning on a prayer in the client:

hh.a(60, (byte)113); //Turn prayer on
((o) (hh)).c.c(117, j2);
hh.c(0);
Ii[j2] = true;
a((byte)-95, il[275]);

Here’s the equivalent I took from an old STS mudclient:

                        super.Connection.SendID(52);
                        super.Connection.SendVar(k2);
                        super.Connection.End();
                        PrayerIsOn[k2] = false;
                        fdb("prayeroff");

What I am doing to invoke this is:

			Method hha = rsgame.getClass().getDeclaredField("hh").getType().getSuperclass().getDeclaredMethod("a", Integer.TYPE, Byte.TYPE);
			hha.setAccessible(true);
			
			Method sendint = rsgame.getClass().getDeclaredField("hh").getType().getSuperclass().getDeclaredField("c").getType().getSuperclass().getDeclaredMethod("c", Integer.TYPE, Integer.TYPE);
			sendint.setAccessible(true);
			
			Method hhc = rsgame.getClass().getDeclaredField("hh").getType().getSuperclass().getDeclaredMethod("c", Integer.TYPE);
			hhc.setAccessible(true);
			
			//Invoke Methods
			hha.invoke(rsgame, new Object[] { new Integer(60), new Byte((byte) 113) } );
			sendint.invoke(rsgame, new Object[] { new Integer(117), new Integer(1) } );
			hhc.invoke(rsgame, new Integer(0));

Yet nothing is happening. I was expecting to turn on prayer[1].

Also this applies to most every useful method in the RuneScape client…

Here you can see STS’s methods:

http://pastebin.com/p81k8Ck7

And the RSC equivalent:

http://pastebin.com/E8aFvLBX

I’m having trouble using any of these because I don’t have access to variables like j1 like STS does.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Err, he actually wants the instance of the client. Accessing loader.h is actually /exactly/ what he wants; this is what you would pass to Method.invoke(). The class instance, if for some reason you need it, can be found by doing loader.h.getClass(), anyways.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.description:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:10, topic:415127”][quote author=DonkeyKongTHDJ link=topic=517086.msg3755803#msg3755803 date=1316447376]
But isn’t “h” what I want anyways? The instance of the client?
[/quote]You want the client class instance, not the applet.[/quote]
localObject5 = ((f)localObject4).loadClass(“client”);
this.h = ((Applet)((Class)localObject5).newInstance());

Read full topic

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“DonkeyKongTHDJ, post:5, topic:415127”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=517086.msg3755529#msg3755529 date=1316402974]

Thank you super_ for your help.

It is now working, but instead of loading the loader.jar I am loading the rsclassic.jar. I was under the impression that you needed to load through the loader for some reason.

It loaded extremely fast via loader.jar, but now it takes maybe a whole minute to load through the rsclassic jar.
[/quote]You can hack the loader and do it though that as well.

I’m not sure how to do that, though.

I was browsing through the loader.class and found this snippet:

        localObject5 = ((f)localObject4).loadClass("client");
        synchronized (this) {
          if (this.b) {
            return;
          }
          this.h = ((Applet)((Class)localObject5).newInstance());
          ((Class)localObject5).getMethod("provideLoaderApplet", new Class[] { p == null ? (loader.p = a("java.applet.Applet")) : p }).invoke(null, new Object[] { this });
          this.h.init();
          if (this.k) {
            this.h.start();
          }
          if (this.n)
          {
            this.h.stop();
          }

this.h is the instance of the client being loaded. Is this what I need to pass as my Object to invoke?[/quote] localObject5 = ((f)localObject4).loadClass("client");

Read full topic

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:4, topic:415127”][quote author=DonkeyKongTHDJ link=topic=517086.msg3755462#msg3755462 date=1316399000]
Thank you super_ for your help.

It is now working, but instead of loading the loader.jar I am loading the rsclassic.jar. I was under the impression that you needed to load through the loader for some reason.

It loaded extremely fast via loader.jar, but now it takes maybe a whole minute to load through the rsclassic jar.
[/quote]You can hack the loader and do it though that as well.[/quote]

I’m not sure how to do that, though.

I was browsing through the loader.class and found this snippet:

        localObject5 = ((f)localObject4).loadClass("client");
        synchronized (this) {
          if (this.b) {
            return;
          }
          this.h = ((Applet)((Class)localObject5).newInstance());
          ((Class)localObject5).getMethod("provideLoaderApplet", new Class[] { p == null ? (loader.p = a("java.applet.Applet")) : p }).invoke(null, new Object[] { this });
          this.h.init();
          if (this.k) {
            this.h.start();
          }
          if (this.n)
          {
            this.h.stop();
          }

this.h is the instance of the client being loaded. Is this what I need to pass as my Object to invoke?

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

You’re passing a Class<?> instance when you should be passing a client instance. Modify the loader so you can access it.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client

item.title: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
item.dc:creator: @DonkeyKongTHDJ DonkeyKongTHDJ
item.description:
@DonkeyKongTHDJ wrote:

I’ve been trying to have a go at making a basic RuneScape Classic bot using reflection, but I’m having trouble using any of the methods inside of the client.

I have the client loaded by the loader.jar with the rsclassic.jar, both downloaded straight off of the RuneScape website. I’m running them off of the local drive rather than the url to the jar on the RS site.

Currently this is all I have:

xn8br4.png538×571

I tried earlier to try to invoke a simple method inside the client, but could never get it working.

I want to invoke the method “G(int i1)” which I believe logs the player out.

This is what I am trying:

Method m = RSL.getClientClass().getDeclaredMethod("G", Integer.TYPE); m.setAccessible(true); Object param = new Integer(2); m.invoke(RSL.getClientClass(), param);

And it always gives me:

object is not an instance of declaring class

I think it is because my loader doesn’t create a new instance of client when it loads, but rather an new instance of loader.

I don’t really know where to go from here. Maybe load the client from the website rather than locally, I don’t know.

Read full topic
item.source: Need help invoking methods in the RuneScape Client
